timeline.message:
Add the PersistableSlidingWindow class

- A PersistableSlidingWindow is a sliding window that aggregates data
into buckets and can be written to and read from the disk. This makes it
suitable for retaining data over large spans of time requiring too much
memory or being susceptible to node loss.

timeline.bodyText:
Is this functionally correct? IIUC, this expects timestampDiff to be in SECONDS, converts it to timeUnit and compares it against bucketSizeMs which is in milliseconds.
Is timeUnit guaranteed to be in ms? Is timestampDiff guaranteed to be in seconds?
timeline.author: vigyasharma

replies.bodyText:
Good catch, fixed and added a UT to catch this.
SlidingWindowData timestamps must be in ms (SlidingWindow assumes this). The bucket length and overall window size can be specified using any timeunit.
replies.author: sidheart

timeline.bodyText:
This class is doing two things, it is providing a persistable sliding window, and it is aggregating (deduping) data points within a bucketization window.
How about we split these responsibilities and have this class focus only on persisting?
Re: the bucketization piece, I have a few more comments - I suppose the motivation for this is to act like an alarm breach monitor which gets set when some thresholds are hit, and unset on a different criteria. This can be used in deciders then, to figure out when an action is relevant (alarm unhealthy) and irrelevant (alarm healthy).
As such, it may be read more often than an issue gets added (next being called) and the sliding window should get updated on each read.
Again, we can move this to a separate PR/class and focus this one primarily on persistence as I see most of the code here pertains to persisting data.
timeline.author: vigyasharma

replies.bodyText: I removed the aggregation logic from this PR.
replies.author: sidheart

The sliding window retains data for slidingWindowSizeInSeconds and aggregates values into time - * buckets of width bucketSizeInSeconds. For example if slidingWindowSizeInSeconds is 86400 (1 day) - * and bucketSizeInSeconds is 3600 (1 hr) then there will be at most 25 data points in the sliding window - * at any given time. It's 25 and not 24 because the oldest datapoints are removed lazily based on - * arrival time. This shouldn't impact most consumers of this data structure. - * - *

The data contained in this sliding window is effectively a time series. Consumers may extend this - * class and define more complex aggregations or analytics functions. */ public class PersistableSlidingWindow extends SlidingWindow { private static final Logger LOG = LogManager.getLogger(PersistableSlidingWindow.class);

timeline.bodyText:
do we want to make rotateFile() synchronized ?
And can we refactor FileRotate class to make it more generic instead of using static to expose its method directly ?
timeline.author: rguo-aws

replies.bodyText:
I made the write and load synchronized, we don't want to make rotateFile synchronized
FileRotate contains a lot of specific logic for logfile rotation with a date prefix. Refactoring it is out of scope. I've made minimal changes to address the thread safety issue you brought up.
replies.author: sidheart

timeline.bodyText: should we do this check within the constructor itself ? I think it would make more sense to perform this check during writing operation.
timeline.author: rguo-aws

replies.bodyText: I don't expose the load function to consumers. This class loads previous data exactly once upon construction. It doesn't need to load during write/next operations.
replies.author: sidheart

replies.bodyText: The reason I create the file here is because I need to do the check before I load. The reason this logic shouldn't live inside write() is because it would waste every single instruction to check beyond the first
replies.author: sidheart

replies.bodyText: I thought about it, and I see what you were getting at. I preserved the load in the constructor, but I removed the create file as it's unnecessary.
replies.author: sidheart

timeline.bodyText: nit: We should use File.separator for compatibility.
timeline.author: ktkrg

replies.bodyText:
File.separator is generally a path separator like '/'
In this case, I'm using a known character to separate data entries in my own file format. I renamed this to DATA_SEPARATOR to hopefully make it more clear.
replies.author: sidheart

replies.bodyText: Thanks, not sure why I said File.separator, I was meaning to say System.lineSeparator(). As long as you use the same separator for reading and writing I'm ok.
replies.author: ktkrg

timeline.bodyText: any reason why we're writing in the reverse sequential order? Won't this bring back the sliding window in the reverse order after a load?
timeline.author: ktkrg

replies.bodyText: This is so that things are in the correct order. Look at how SlidingWindow stores data in a LinkedList on calls to next(). Also see PersistableSlidingWindowTest#testNext(). I added an extra case to this function for extra sanity as well.
replies.author: sidheart

replies.bodyText: ha! We offerFirst() and pollLast(), it makes sense now.

timeline.bodyText: Do we really need to wrap this into an IllegalArgumentException? We could leave this as the checked IOException. It will ensure that callers handle it gracefully.
timeline.author: vigyasharma

replies.bodyText: file could be accidentally deleted by operator or even some other process(i.e. log pusher). should we create a new file in case IOException occurs ?
replies.author: rguo-aws

replies.bodyText:
I've changed this not to throw. If we can't load data on construction we'll just log an error.
A caller who is expecting data to be loaded can check if the window is empty.
A deleted/moved file issue will be resolved on the next call to write() as it includes an atomic move operation.
replies.author: sidheart
